summary.value:
Study 2 rationale; additions to Study 1. 
We will build on Study 1 by next looking at participants’ ratings of generic and specific statements. In the first study, the specifics were always explicitly contrasted with the generic statements. Also, the Study 1 task involved evaluating what generic and specific statements implied about a speaker. In this study, participants will read vignettes and then rate the accuracy of generic and specific statements. The vignettes and the statements describing them will either involve Structural properties or Stereotypical properties (i.e., inaccurate traits and values sometimes associated with Black people). Here we will also consider both ‘positive’ and ‘negative’ stereotypical generic statements (In Study 1, all generics about stereotypes were negatively valanced). 
Hypotheses. 
1.	We suspect that without the pragmatic context the specific statements may be rated high across conditions. In a description of a specific event, a generic (“Black people face workplace discrimination”) and specific (“She faced workplace discrimination”) can both be accurate. This would underline the pragmatic implications of using specifics that explicitly deny generics or which tacitly deny them through their exclusion (as occurred in Study 1).  
2.	We expected that the relative accuracy of generic and specific statements would differ by condition, such that participants will believe generic statements about structural regularities are more accurate than generic statements about traits and values. 
3.	We expected that this condition difference would be moderated by participant race and participant racism. We expected Black participants to show a particularly strong belief that generics about structural properties are accurate and generics about stereotypes are inaccurate. We expected this pattern of results (generics about structural properties as more accurate than generics about stereotypical properties) to be weakest in participants high in racism.  
Sample size. 
We selected the same sample size as Study 1 based on the same rationale: 100 participants per condition (generics about structural properties, generics about stereotypes) per race (Black, White), to give us 95% power to detect medium effect sizes (d = .50). 
Design and Procedure.
Participants will read 4 short descriptions of an individual. The stories evoked either structural forms of discrimination or evoked racial stereotypes (between subject). Participants were then asked to rate the accuracy of two statements: One that was generic and one that was specific (within subject). Participants then answered a battery of questions assessing racial bias: Symbolic racism, White-Black social dominance, and feeling thermometers. 



Stimuli.
[Short description]
Below you will see two ways of characterizing this event. Rate the accuracy of each of these descriptions of the event.

[Generic] 
[Specific]

Scale: Very Inaccurate - Mostly inaccurate - Slightly inaccurate - Slightly accurate - Mostly accurate -Very accurate

Short descriptions and generic / specific statements. 

Structural. 
A Black man received a text from his boss saying that his natural hair was unprofessional. He confronted his employer, who apologized. The following week he took a sick day; his boss called and told him he was being let go due to his poor work ethic.
"Black people face workplace discrimination."
"He faced workplace discrimination."
A Black woman went to an expensive clothing store. The clerk followed her and assumed she did not belong. The clerk kept asking if she needed help and kept closely watching her when she said no.
“Black people are treated with suspicion”
“She was treated with suspicion” 
A Black woman arranged for her son to attend a school in the neighboring town. Although she did not live in that school's district, her relative did. On enrollment forms, she listed the address of her relative so that her son would qualify. When this was discovered, she was convicted of a felony and served jail time.
"Black people are treated unfairly by the criminal justice system."
"She was treated unfairly by the criminal justice system."
A young Black man went to his guidance counselor. He had been performing reasonably well in school and wanted to attend university. His counselor began the discussion by talking about the military. When he said that's not what he wanted to do, she switched gears to discussing the local community college. She never explained how to apply to 4-year universities. He walked away unsure whether that was the right path for him.
"Black people are given fewer opportunities for success."
"He was given fewer opportunities for success."
Stereotypical.
A Black man received a text from his boss saying that his work ethic was unprofessional. He was missing work every other week and was regularly late to meetings. At work, his boss often found him sitting at his desk with his legs up and his eyes closed. When his boss confronted him, he said that he didn't want to take work too seriously.
"Black people don't value hard work."
"He didn't value hard work."
A Black woman had an income that was just sufficient to support herself and her family without having to worry too much. However, she took up huge amounts of credit card debt due to spending binges where she would buy expensive jewelry and state-of-the-art electronics. Eventually, she had trouble paying for her rent and groceries due to the amount of debt she was in.
"Black people are irresponsible with their money."
"She was irresponsible with their money."
A young Black man recently tried out for the track team. He had never run competitively before but he performed better than some of the men already on the team. The coach said he was a natural. He even went to the state tournament that season and placed in the top three.
"Black people are athletically gifted."
"He is athletically gifted."
A Black woman started college last semester and started going to a cappella groups. She had been singing for years in church groups in her neighborhood. Due to her training and passion for singing, she had a powerful voice. She became one of the lead singers in the group and was often asked to perform solos. 
"Black people are good at singing."
"She is good at singing."
 
Questions about participants attitudes
1.	Symbolic racism scale, brief. 
a.	Q1. Irish, Italian, Jewish, and many other minorities overcame prejudice and worked their way up. Black people should do the same. Black people are demanding too much from the rest of society.
b.	Q2. Black people are demanding too much from the rest of society.
c.	Q3. Discrimination against Black people is no longer a problem in the United States.
2.	Social dominance orientation about White/Black 
a.	If Black people stayed in their place, we would have fewer problems.
b.	It is okay if White people have more of a chance in today’s society than Black people.
c.	Black people are simply inferior to White people.
d.	People should be given an equal chance in life regardless of whether they are Black or White. (Reverse-coded)
e.	We should do what we can to equalize conditions between Black and White people. (Reverse-coded)
f.	It would be good if Black and White people could be equal. (Reverse-coded)
Demographics
1.	Political orientation: Very Conservative. Conservative. Moderate. Liberal. Very Liberal.
2.	Gender: Man. Woman. Genderqueer. Other. Prefer not to answer.
3.	Race: White, Black, Other (we are specifically recruiting White and Black participants from Turk Prime panels, so all participants should be White or Black). 
 
Analyses. 
Primary analyses.
Analysis 1: Using a multi-level model, we will examine whether ratings of generic vs. specific statements (Generic) depend on whether the descriptions are Structural or Stereotypical (Condition). We predict a significant interaction. The relative accuracy of specific statements compared to generic statements will depend on condition, such that specifics will be more accurate than generics primarily in the Stereotypical condition.  
lmer(Rating ~ Generic*Condition + (Generic/Participant), data = df)
Follow-ups: We will then explore whether this interaction is moderated by participant race or racism. 
lmer(Rating ~ Generic*Condition*Race + (Generic/Participant), data = df)
lmer(Rating ~ Generic*Condition*Racism+ (Generic/Participant), data = df) 
Racism corresponds to a composite of the three racism measures. 
Additional considerations.
1.	An important additional analysis concerns whether the valence of generics about stereotypes matter. We will compare whether positive stereotypes are rated higher than negative stereotypes. We will compare whether the difference between positive and negative stereotypes is larger for White participants than Black participants. We will consider whether racism is a stronger predictor of negative stereotypes than positive stereotypes. Overall though, we predict that our hypotheses will hold for both positive and negative stereotypes rather than being valence-specific. 
2.	We suspect that the best predictor of the three racism measures will be symbolic racism. Symbolic racism corresponds to a particular causal-explanatory belief about whether Black people are responsible for their lower social position or not. We will explore this possibility and report the relative predictive power of each measure.
3.	It may be worth considering the distributions of ratings. Presumably there will be a wider distribution of responses to generics of structural properties than generics about stereotypes (where variation may be suppressed due to social desirability). Also, participants may vary in how they interpret specific statements. Some participants may rate specifics as uniformly high since they are true descriptions of the story. Other participants may rate them lower than generic statements if they rate their accuracy in relationship to generics – that is, they may believe generic statements are better descriptions than specific statements.

attributes.title: Style Priming Affects Perception of Primary Triads

q1.value: Style Priming Affects Perception of Primary Triads

q3.value: This is a replication of Hughes 2011, in which two-chord progressions were primed by either classical or rock music. Participants rated the two-chord progressions for goodness-of-fit. The progressions always contained a primary triad (I, IV, or V) in either the first or second position. The remaining chord contained a secondary triad built upon either a diatonic scale degree (ii, iii, or vi) or its flattened counterpart (bii, biii, bvi). The secondary chords were always minor triads.

q4.value:
H1: The primary triad used will have a main effect on rating, whereby progressions containing I will be rated highest, followed by V, and then IV. 

H2. There will be an interaction between style (classical or rock) and primary triad (I, IV, and V). Classical-primed progressions will receive higher ratings when containing I or V than when containing IV. Ratings for rock-primed progressions will show no significant difference between the three primary triads.  

H3. There will be a main effect of diatonicism, whereby ratings for diatonic progressions will be higher than ratings for chromatic progressions. 

H4. There will be an interaction between style and diatonicism. Classical-primed progressions will receive higher ratings for diatonic progressions than chromatic progressions. Rock-primed progressions will also receive higher ratings for diatonic progressions, but the difference between ratings for the two types of progressions will be less pronounced, creating an interaction. 

H5. We predict a main effect of chord order. We predict ratings for progressions ending on primary triads to be higher than those ending on other triads. 

We predict no main effect of style.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study is a 2 (style) x 3 (primary triad) x 2 (ordering) x 6 (secondary triad) within-subjects design. 

Trials consisted of a style prime, followed by a two-chord progression. The style prime consisted of one of two commercial recordings that established the key of Eb major. The classical prime was drawn from the first movement of Mozart‘s Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra No. 10 in Eb Major K. 365. The rock prime was drawn from the recording "Boot Hill," by Stevie Ray Vaughn and Double Trouble. The two-chord progression consisted of one primary triad (I, IV, or V) and one secondary triad (ii, bii, iii, biii, vi, or bvi), presented in either order. The triads that followed these contextual cues were constructed with three Shepard tones to control for any influence of chord inversion or register.

Following each trial, participants were asked:

"How well did the two chords fit within the larger musical context?  Rate on a scale from 1 to 6, with 1 being fits POORLY, and 6 being fits VERY WELL"

Trials were blocked by style, with all rock primes grouped together, and all classical primes grouped together. 

Participants were given five practice trials selected randomly from of the blocks before beginning the experiment proper.

q9.value: Trials were blocked by style (rock, classical). Within each block, trials were randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data were collected via OpenSesame and not analyzed prior to registration.

question.value: Participants were recruited from undergraduate music courses at The University of Lethbridge. Participants who were enrolled as students are offered an extra credit grade for their participation.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 35 participants. We will attempt to recruit 40 participants, assuming that some will not complete the study.

q14.value: This sample size is in accordance to the samples collected from previous tonal hierarchy studies: Krumhansl & Shepard (1979), N=24; Krumhansl & Kessler (1982),  N = 10, 14, Vuvan, Prince, & Schmuckler (2011),  N=16.

q15.value: We will terminate data collection when we reach 40 participants, or when the window for collecting data in the 2019 Fall semester ends.

question.value:
Style: Rock and Classical. The style prime consisted of one of two commercial recordings that established the key of Eb major. The classical prime was drawn from the first movement of Mozart‘s Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra No. 10 in Eb Major K. 365. The rock prime was drawn from the recording "Boot Hill," by Stevie Ray Vaughn and Double Trouble. 

Primary Chord: I, IV, or V

Secondary Chord: ii, bii, iii, biii, vi, bvi

Primary Chord Order: First or Second
Participants rated the two-chord successions on a goodness-of-fit scale from 1-6, with 1 being "fits very poorly" and 6 being "fits very well."
All hypotheses will be tested using a repeated-measures ANOVA.

q20.value: Secondary chord will be re-coded as follows: diatonic (ii, iii, and vi) and chromatic (bii, biii, bvi).

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they fail to complete the experiment, or are observed by the experimenter not to understand or follow the instructions during the experiment.

q23.value: Data will only be analyzed if the participant completes the experiment.

registration_responses.q3: This is a replication of Hughes 2011, in which two-chord progressions were primed by either classical or rock music. Participants rated the two-chord progressions for goodness-of-fit. The progressions always contained a primary triad (I, IV, or V) in either the first or second position. The remaining chord contained a secondary triad built upon either a diatonic scale degree (ii, iii, or vi) or its flattened counterpart (bii, biii, bvi). The secondary chords were always minor triads.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: The primary triad used will have a main effect on rating, whereby progressions containing I will be rated highest, followed by V, and then IV. 

H2. There will be an interaction between style (classical or rock) and primary triad (I, IV, and V). Classical-primed progressions will receive higher ratings when containing I or V than when containing IV. Ratings for rock-primed progressions will show no significant difference between the three primary triads.  

H3. There will be a main effect of diatonicism, whereby ratings for diatonic progressions will be higher than ratings for chromatic progressions. 

H4. There will be an interaction between style and diatonicism. Classical-primed progressions will receive higher ratings for diatonic progressions than chromatic progressions. Rock-primed progressions will also receive higher ratings for diatonic progressions, but the difference between ratings for the two types of progressions will be less pronounced, creating an interaction. 

H5. We predict a main effect of chord order. We predict ratings for progressions ending on primary triads to be higher than those ending on other triads. 

We predict no main effect of style.

attributes.title: Moral Universalism and the Structure of Ideology

q1.value: Moral Universalism and the Structure of Ideology

q2.value: Benjamin Enke | Ricardo Rodriguez-Padilla | Florian Zimmermann

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Attempt to understand the relationship between universalism (in altruism and trust) and policy preferences regarding redistribution, health care, affirmative action, foreign aid, environmental protection, military, police and law enforcement, and border control.

q16.value: Based on a simple model, we hypothesize that experimental and survey measures of universalism in altruism and trust correlate positively with survey measures of support for the first five policies listed above, and negatively with support for the last three policies listed above.

q17.value: By correlating survey measures of universalism with survey measures of these policy preferences. Universalism will be measured using hypothetical allocation tasks in which respondents split hypothetical money or hypothetical between individuals that are either socially close or distant to them.

q18.value: United States, Germany, France, Sweden, Australia, Brazil, South Korea

attributes.title: Comparing the influence of inclusion vs. assimilation on group identification and well-being when inclusion becomes a necessity.
attributes.description: Following ODT (Brewer, 1991), we will test the premise that inclusion (conceptualized as the combination of assimilation and differentiation needs) predicts group identification and well-being  better than assimilation alone. The prediction of group affiliation status on identity and well-being is suggested by the Inclusion Identification Model (IIM; Adams et al., in prep). Due to theoretical considerations, we expect that the superior prediction of inclusion over assimilation will only hold when inclusion becomes a necessity (i.e., when it is relevant to the individual to be both assimilated and differentiated). This pre-registration describes a 2 (differentiation: high vs. low) x 2 (inclusion necessity: high vs. low) lab experiment.

q1.value: Comparing the Effects of Inclusion vs. Assimilation on Group Identification and Well-Being When Inclusion Becomes a Necessity

q3.value:
Although the claim made by Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT; Brewer, 1991) that inclusion (assimilation + differentiation needs) predicts group identification and well-being better than assimilation only, it has, to our knowledge, never been tested. Recent attempts to experimentally manipulate the two dimensions fell short in distinguishing them, such that participants generalized one dimension over the other. Assuming that inclusion might perhaps only have superior prediction over assimilation if inclusion becomes a necessity (i.e., if it is relevant that both dimensions are satisfied), we test inclusion vs. assimilation while manipulating the necessity to be included. This pre-registration describes a 2 (differentiation: high vs. low) x 2 (inclusion necessity: high vs. low) lab experiment. 

For an overview of the ODT model, please see Figure 1 in the summary document (under design plan).

q4.value:
•	Following the Inclusion Identification Model (IIM; Adams et al., in prep.) 
o	H1: The inclusion condition will, compared to the assimilation condition, show higher level of well-being (Hypothesis 1).
o	H2: The inclusion condition will, compared to the assimilation condition, show higher levels of both superordinate and subordinate group identification (Hypothesis 2). 
o	H3: Higher levels of superordinate and subordinate group identity will positively predict well-being (Hypothesis 3).
o	H4: Both superordinate and subordinate group identity will fully mediate the effect of inclusion and, to a weaker extent, assimilation, on well-being (Hypothesis 4). 
•	Following Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT; Brewer, 1991)
o	H5: The mediational model using inclusion as a predictor will have superior model fit than the model using assimilation as a predictor (Hypothesis 5) 
•	Following inclusion necessity arguments (Master’s Thesis Luca Versteegen)
o	H6: The mediation hypothesized in H4 will only occur when inclusion is a necessity, namely when the goal is relevant enough to make productivity a must (Hypothesis 6)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The study will have two parts. In part 1, participants will register, provide demographic information, and baseline measures of mood, group identities, and well-being. In part 2, participants will take a knowledge test including study-related and cultural questions to represent their student group. Using a two-factorial 2 (differentiation: high vs. low) x 2 (inclusion necessity: high vs. low) between subjects design, participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions. In the two high differentiation conditions, participants will receive culture questions about their own country, allowing them to feel needed as an individual. None of these questions will appear in the differentiation low conditions. In the two inclusion necessity conditions, participants will read that this test is not only to represent their student group, but the best group will get a financial incentive, as well as the best individuals student group. None of these incentives will appear in the inclusion necessity low conditions.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to one of four question blocks in Qualtrics that contain the incentive structure (inclusion necessity manipulation) and the cultural questions (differentiation manipulation). Qualtrics will be set to distribute participants evenly across conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: NA, as no existing data will be analyzed.

question.value:
Participants will be Tilburg University undergraduate psychology students. They will register via the Tilburg University Online Research Participation System SONA. 

Participants will be compensated with course credit. In the two inclusion necessity high conditions, participants will additionally read that they can get two incentives. The first, a collective incentive for the best student group, will not be paid and debriefed as cover after the study. The second, an individual incentive for outstanding cultural knowledge (20€), will be paid to the best five students of these two conditions. 

Participants must be at least 18 years of old and registered undergraduate psychology students to participate. Participants must have agreed to the informed consent to participate.

q13.value: The required sample size for this study is N = 280 (n = 70). We will attempt to recruit N = 350 to account for uncomplete participations.

q14.value: We conducted a power analyses using the R findRMSEAsamplesize function and guidance by MacCallum, Browne, & Sugaware (1996) to have a sufficient power of 1-ß = .8, alpha = .05, Null-RMSEA = .05, Alternative RMSEA = .08. Additionally, power analyses using G*Power 3 (Faul, Erdfelder, & Buchner, & Lang, 2009) suggested that this sample size will suffice for regression analyses.

q15.value: We will collect data until the required sample size of N = 350 is achieved. Should we not attain this sample size within three weeks, we will stop dat collection if the given sample exceeds N = 280.

question.value:
Factor 1: Differentiation: All participants will receive nine culture-related questions. In the differentiation high condition, three of those questions will be about the participants' home country and thus allow that she contributes to the group task with her subgroup knowledge. In the differentiation low condition, all nine questions will be about different countries, thus not allowing participants to provide subgroup knowledge. 

Factor 2: Inclusion necessity: In the high inclusion necessity conditions, the test will be announced to be financially incentivized. First, there will be a collective prize for the best study group. Second, there will be an individual prize for the best individual performance on the culture questions. Belonging (assimilation) and being authentically unique (differentiation) will thus both matter to the participant (inclusion). In the low inclusion necessity condition, no such incentives will be given, such that it should not matter to the participant to be included. 

Note than the level of belonging (assimilation need) is high in both groups, such that all participants belong to the group of psychology students.

Superordinate psychology student identity: 6-item Marketing Professional Identity Scale (Bennett, 2010) to assess the psychological profession. An example item is “I feel strongly that I am a member of this profession.” (all 1 (Disagree very strongly) – 7 (Agree very strongly)). 

Subordinate national identity: 6-item adapted from Huddy and Khatib (2007). E.g, “Being American is very important to me.” (All 1 (Strongly disagree)- 5 (Strongly agree)).
Subordinate ethnic/cultural identity: We will additionally assess the 6-item Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM; Phinney, 1992). E.g., “I have a strong sense of belonging to my own ethnic group” using the same option response range to assess ethnic identity.” (All 1 (Strongly disagree)- 5 (Strongly agree)). 
oThe reason to administer both scales is that we manipulate in the cultural context and thus do not expect national ID to be directly affected (which would suggest to use the Huddy & Khatib scale), nor do we expect ethnic identity to be directly affected (which would suggest the use of Phinney’s scale). As the form of subordinate national identity that we are interested in is very cultural, we will assess psychometrics for both scales and see which offers more information. We will report the use and potential exclusion of any of the scales transparently. 
 
Life Satisfaction Well-Being: six-item Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985). E.g.; "If I could live my life over, I would change almost nothing." (all 1 (Strongly disagree) – 7 (Strongly agree). 

Self-efficacy Well-Being: 8-item New General Self-Efficacy Scale (NGSE; Chen, Gully, & Eden, 2001). An example item is “I will be able to achieve most of the goals that I have set for myself” (all 1 (Strongly disagree) – 5 (Strongly agree)). 

o	We will further assess the following demographic and control variables: Age (free entry), Gender (Male, Female, Other, Don’t want to say), Native language (English, English among others, Not English), Religion (Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism, None, Orthodox, Other: free entry), Highest Education (Less than High School, High School/GED, Some College or Associate’s Degree, Bachelor’s Degree, Graduate Degree, Other: free entry), Employment status (Full-time, part-time, self-employed, student, Homemaker, unemployed/looking for work, retired, other: free entry), Political Ideology (5-option Likert scale: extremely liberal – extremely conservative), Home country (selection of 32 European countries that were registered in the Tilburg University Psychology Bachelor studies), GPA/average grade (free entry), interest in other countries and cultures (1 (Very slightly/not at all)-5 (Extremely)), interest in travelling (1 (Very slightly/not at all)-5 (Extremely)).

We will compute a mean score for the following measures: 
– Superordinate psychological identity
– Subordinate ethnic/cultural identity
– Life satisfaction well-being
– Self-efficacy well-being
– Positive Affect
– Negative Affect

We will first conduct preliminary analyses to examine missingness of data, outliers, and influential data points. Next, we will examine psychometrics and factor structure of all scales, as well as descriptive analyses (Means) and correlation analyses. 

To test the hypotheses, we will conduct hierarchical regression for the following outcomes. 
1. Hypothesis 1: We will regress each well-being variable (life satisfaction and self-esteem) on three models separately (Model 1: demographics, Model 2: Demographics + positive and negative affect; Model 3: Demographics + positive and negative affect + Condition)
2. Hypothesis 2: We will regress the superordinate professional identity and the subordinate national identity on three models separately (Model 1: demographics, Model 2: Demographics + positive and negative affect; Model 3: Demographics + positive and negative affect + Condition)
3. Hypothesis 3: We will regress each well-being variable (life satisfaction and self-esteem) on three models separately  (Model 1: demographics, Model 2: Demographics + positive and negative affect; Model 3: Demographics + positive and negative affect + superordinate and subordinate identity)
4. Hypothesis 4: We will regress each well-being variable (life satisfaction and self-esteem) on four models separately  (Model 1: demographics, Model 2: Demographics + positive and negative affect; Model 3: Demographics + positive and negative affect + superordinate and subordinate identity; Model 4: Demographics + positive and negative affect + superordinate and subordinate identity + Condition)
5. Hypothesis 5: We will compare model fit in Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) using the R-package lavaan to compare two models (Model 1: using the two full inclusion conditions (assimilation + differentiation); Model 2: using the two simple inclusion conditions (assimilation only) as predictors)).
6. Hypothesis 6: We will compare model fit in Structural Equation Modeling (SEM using the R-package lavaan to compare two models (Model 1: using the two low inclusion necessity conditions (no incentives); Model 2: using the two high inclusion necessity conditions (incentives) as predictors).

q20.value:
Reverse-coded items in the scales will be recoded. As indicated above, a mean score will be computed for the two identity, the two well-being, and the two affect scales. 

Categorical background variables (native language, religion, education, employment status, political ideology, and home country) as well as the condition will be dummy coded. 

No other data transformation is intended by now.

q21.value:
We will use p < .05 as criterion of significance, as well as the adequate effect size in hierarchical regression and SEM. 
In case of multiple comparisons, we will use the post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test as a correction tool.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who do not pass the attention check or whose response to the study purpose question suggest that they have uncovered the actual study purpose. We will further exclude participants who show extremely short or long test durations or any abnormal patterns suggesting that they did not pay attention to or take the study seriously.

q23.value: The cause of potential missingness will be examined through missingness simulations and, in case of missingness not at random (MNAR, Scheffer, 2002), I will conduct maximum likelihood imputation.

q24.value:
We will follow the modification indices provide in SEM to explore if other theoretical considerations provide better fit. This will be done when backed up by theory and substantial reasoning. 

We will further explore if any demographics (especially particular countries) affect single variables or the general statistical results. 

As we are especially expecting Dutch and German participants, it might be fruitful to examine differences between majority and minority groups if these analyses are sufficiently powered. 

In case the manipulation is not successful, we will consider conducting Principle Component Analysis (PCA) to find potential other groups that can be grouped based on the experience of assimilation, differentiation, and inclusion necessity variables.

q25.value: Note that the first dimension of inclusion, assimilation, will be high in all four conditions (by establishing the cover that participants will be competing for psychology students). This dimension is not manipulated.

attributes.title: scripts_2020-02-07
attributes.description: zip archive concerning all data extraction and data cleaning scripts

summary.value: This is an update of the previous registration. It follows the fact that we realised that the textual corpus  we worked with is substantially incomplete. Therefore we decided to build a new dataset and a set of new tools for working with it (new lemmatization, new temporal metadata). The new dataset consists from 1458 deduplicated documents and 34,589,083 words. As in the case of the previous dataset, we will work only with a subselection of these, i.e. only with documents which are (1) at least to some extent datable (on the century basis), (2) which emerged before or at the year 400 CE, and (3) which might be classified as being either of "christian" or "pagan" provenience (i.e. not "jewish"). There is at least 867 of such documents, but perhaps even more than that. The uploaded scripts represent a snapshot of our workflow before we started to analyse these new data in respect to our research question.

registration_responses.summary: This is an update of the previous registration. It follows the fact that we realised that the textual corpus  we worked with is substantially incomplete. Therefore we decided to build a new dataset and a set of new tools for working with it (new lemmatization, new temporal metadata). The new dataset consists from 1458 deduplicated documents and 34,589,083 words. As in the case of the previous dataset, we will work only with a subselection of these, i.e. only with documents which are (1) at least to some extent datable (on the century basis), (2) which emerged before or at the year 400 CE, and (3) which might be classified as being either of "christian" or "pagan" provenience (i.e. not "jewish"). There is at least 867 of such documents, but perhaps even more than that. The uploaded scripts represent a snapshot of our workflow before we started to analyse these new data in respect to our research question.

attributes.title: Replication and Extension Maas et al. 2012 (TAR)
attributes.description: We replicate and extend the study 'In Search of Informed Discretion: An Experimental Investigation of Fairness and Trust Reciprocity' by Maas, van Rinsum, and Towry (2012), published in The Accounting Review.

q2.value: Victor van Pelt, Jesse van der Geest, Bart Dierynck

q3.value: We replicate the study 'In Search of Informed Discretion: An Experimental Investigation of Fairness and Trust Reciprocity' by Maas, van Rinsum, and Towry (2012), published in The Accounting Review. The goal of our replication is twofold. First, we replicate the original study, in which supervisor-participants use a one-stage process to express their willingness to pay for information. Second, we introduce an extension in which supervisor-participants use a two-stage process to express their willingness to pay for information. Specifically, rather than immediately choosing their willingness to pay for information, we will first ask supervisor-participants whether they would like to choose their willingness to pay for information. Only if their answer is "yes," we will ask them how much they are willing to pay for the information.

q4.value: We predict that supervisor-participants' willingness to pay is lower under a two-stage process in the extension than under a one-stage process in the replication.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design with one factor (the type of information search process) and 2 levels (two-stage versus one-stage).

q9.value: We will randomly allocate groups of participants in a particular experimental session to one of the two levels of our between subjects factor.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from an economics subject pool at a large Western European university. We send out an invitation to participate in the experiment via e-mail to everyone registered in the subject pool. Participants can self-select into sessions via an opt-in system. Hence, participation is voluntary. We pay participants based on their choices in a similar fashion to the original study conducted by Maas et al (2012 The Accounting Review). Specifically, we paid 0.5 Euro per Lira, which is the currency used in the experiment.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 216 participants. Specifically, we are aiming for 36 participants times 3 for each of the two levels of our between subject's factor.

q14.value: The original study by Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review) has 126 participants for one treatment. Thus, with budgetary constraints, we tried to match their sample size as closely as possible for  the two levels of our between subject's factor.

question.value: We will manipulate whether the information search process of the supervisor is one-stage versus two-stage. Specifically, our replication of Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review) has a one-stage process where the supervisor immediately expresses his or her willingness to pay information between 0 Lira and 5 Lira with increments of 0.1 Lira. Our extension has a two-stage process in which the supervisor first chooses whether to offer a price for information (0 Lira or more Lira) and if so how much (0.1 Lira to 5 Lira).
Our primary dependent variable is the supervisors' willingness to pay for information measured from 0 Lira through 5 Lira with increments of 0.1 Lira.

We will replicate the tests in Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review) as much as possible and test for differences between our replication and our extension. We will do so in a way that is consistent with the original tests used in Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review).

registration_responses.q2: Victor van Pelt, Jesse van der Geest, Bart Dierynck
registration_responses.q3: We replicate the study 'In Search of Informed Discretion: An Experimental Investigation of Fairness and Trust Reciprocity' by Maas, van Rinsum, and Towry (2012), published in The Accounting Review. The goal of our replication is twofold. First, we replicate the original study, in which supervisor-participants use a one-stage process to express their willingness to pay for information. Second, we introduce an extension in which supervisor-participants use a two-stage process to express their willingness to pay for information. Specifically, rather than immediately choosing their willingness to pay for information, we will first ask supervisor-participants whether they would like to choose their willingness to pay for information. Only if their answer is "yes," we will ask them how much they are willing to pay for the information.
registration_responses.q4: We predict that supervisor-participants' willingness to pay is lower under a two-stage process in the extension than under a one-stage process in the replication.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: We will randomly allocate groups of participants in a particular experimental session to one of the two levels of our between subjects factor.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 216 participants. Specifically, we are aiming for 36 participants times 3 for each of the two levels of our between subject's factor.
registration_responses.q14: The original study by Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review) has 126 participants for one treatment. Thus, with budgetary constraints, we tried to match their sample size as closely as possible for  the two levels of our between subject's factor.
registration_responses.q8.question: Between subjects design with one factor (the type of information search process) and 2 levels (two-stage versus one-stage).
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited from an economics subject pool at a large Western European university. We send out an invitation to participate in the experiment via e-mail to everyone registered in the subject pool. Participants can self-select into sessions via an opt-in system. Hence, participation is voluntary. We pay participants based on their choices in a similar fashion to the original study conducted by Maas et al (2012 The Accounting Review). Specifically, we paid 0.5 Euro per Lira, which is the currency used in the experiment.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate whether the information search process of the supervisor is one-stage versus two-stage. Specifically, our replication of Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review) has a one-stage process where the supervisor immediately expresses his or her willingness to pay information between 0 Lira and 5 Lira with increments of 0.1 Lira. Our extension has a two-stage process in which the supervisor first chooses whether to offer a price for information (0 Lira or more Lira) and if so how much (0.1 Lira to 5 Lira).
registration_responses.q17.question: Our primary dependent variable is the supervisors' willingness to pay for information measured from 0 Lira through 5 Lira with increments of 0.1 Lira.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will replicate the tests in Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review) as much as possible and test for differences between our replication and our extension. We will do so in a way that is consistent with the original tests used in Maas et al. (2012 The Accounting Review).
